abstract.t: While individuals may choose their own Cascading Style Sheet for presenting HTML-formatted RFCs, the default offered by the RFC Editor must meet certain requirements. This draft describes those requirements.
Discussion of this draft takes place on the rfc-interest mailing list (rfc-interest@rfc-editor.org), which has its home page at https://www.rfc-editor.org/mailman/listinfo/rfc-interest.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The HTML format for RFCs, described in assigns style guidance to an RFC Editor-defined Cascading Style Sheet (CSS). This CSS will be embedded in the published HTML, and may be overridden by a locally defined CSS as desired. The embedded, default CSS as included by the RFC Editor is expected to take into account accessibility needs and be built along a responsive design model.
This document describes the requirements for the default CSS used by the RFC Editor. The requirements will only be applied to HTML documents published as per .

section.title: Design Goal
section.t: RFCs must be adaptable to a wide variety of devices and displays, accessible to assisted readers, and printable.

list.t: Support the display of the semantic HTML described in .
Follow best practice for accessibility, as defined by the W3C's "Best Practices for Authoring HTML" .
Follow best practice for mobile devices, as defined by the W3C's "Best Practices for Authoring HTML."
Allow for a broad range of internationalized scripts.

section.title: Title Page Header
section.t: The document header must be at the top of the page and include all information described in the "Style Guide" and "RFC Streams, Headers, and Boilerplates"

section.title: Body
section.t: The body of the document must conform to the following:

list.t: Examples and code blocks must be in a fixed-width font
ASCII art must be in a fixed-width font
Reflow the text as the screen gets smaller and limit max width
Tables must allow for distinct header rows
Paragraphs should include a hover-over paragraph identifier
Default to a sans-serif font family with broad Unicode support for web browser viewing.
Default to a serif font family with broad Unicode support for printing.
A fixed-width font must be used for code and artwork-tagged sections.
All fonts should be publicly licensed and supported by all major web browsers.
Further specification regarding font families TBD

section.title: Printing
section.t: The CSS must include support for a printer-friendly output. The print rules should be a part of the embedded style sheet; consumers of an RFC may develop their own print-specific style sheet as desired.

section.title: CSS Classes and Attributes
section.t: This section describes the CSS classes specific to RFCs. Basic selectors are not described.

section.title: .art-
section.t: These classes will mostly be styled as part of .artwork. Specific classes may include '.art-ascii-art' and '.art-svg'.

section.title: .artwork
section.t: To float, or not to float?

section.title: .bcp14
section.t: This will not result in any special action on the part of the RFC Editor CSS. Local CSS files may choose to highlight or otherwise emphasize keywords identified with this tag.

section.title: .cref
section.t: A comment within an I-D; should be visually distinct.
For I-Ds only; not for RFCs.

section.title: .rfceditor-remove
section.t: A note to be added after the standard boilerplage. Make visually distinct to highlight final removal of the note by the RFC Editor.
For I-Ds only; not for RFCs.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Security vulnerabilities can be introduced through the CSS. How much detail do we need to go into here to say "don't do foolish things and introduce security issues?"

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This draft contains no action for IANA
